docs.lead_paragraph: ENRON gave off flashes of brilliance even as its financial wizardry and creative accounting spun the company out of control. These flashes could merely have been bubbles bursting, or they might have been something far greater -- glimpses of the future. Historically, innovative ideas are incorporated into the economic system only through a painful shakedown process. Often, these new ideas have signaled a sea change in the economic order of things, but the system often readjusted only after a brutal upheaval.

docs.lead_paragraph: Descending from the fog-shrouded 50th-floor office of Kenneth L. Lay, the patriarch of the Enron Corporation, Jesse Jackson strode into the gray morning today and approached the television cameras. The moment seemed ripe for a familiar flourish of indignation and versification. But if Mr. Jackson did describe Enron's collapse as a metaphor for problems in American corporate culture, if he did seem less than impressed with the actions of President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, his comments were also notable for what they did not include -- a jab at Mr. Lay.

The prosecutor, Andrew Weissmann, chief of the criminal division of the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn and the lead prosecutor in the 1997 trial that ended with the imprisonment of the reputed head of the Genovese crime family, is described by colleagues as a tenacious investigator and litigator.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kenneth L. Lay resigned this evening as chairman and chief executive of the Enron Corporation under pressure from outside creditors, nearly two months after his company filed for one of the largest bankruptcies in the history of American business. Mr. Lay, 59, suggested in a statement that he had decided to resign ''in cooperation'' with the court-appointed creditors committee that is overseeing the bankruptcy proceedings. He said the various federal inquiries into Enron's collapse were too large a distraction as he tried to resuscitate the company he has led since 1986.

docs.snippet: As the workers who lost their retirement savings in Enron stock demonstrated, Americans are not always the best investors. And sometimes their companies set up incentives that can make things worse.     Many Enron workers saved mainly through thei...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the workers who lost their retirement savings in Enron stock demonstrated, Americans are not always the best investors. And sometimes their companies set up incentives that can make things worse. Many Enron workers saved mainly through their 401(k) retirement plans, and chose to keep their 401(k) money mostly or entirely in Enron stock. Financial advisers say it is wiser to choose a mix of investments.
docs.abstract: Loss of retirement savings by Enron Corp employees who chose to keep their 401 (k) money mostly or entirely in Enron stock highlights failure of many workers to follow expert advice to diversify holdings; Enron, like many employers, discouraged diversification by matching workers' contributions only with own stock; Enron's corporate culture also spurred employees to put own contributions into Enron stock, so that 60 percent of 401 (k) assets were reportedly in such stock just before collapse; experts suggest improvements on similar pension models used by other big companies; graphs (M)
